newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries well bid ahead of claims, auction.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries well bid ahead of claims, auction.

text.p: The prices of U.S. Treasury securities were slightly higher Thursday morning after gaining slightly overnight in Europe.
The long bond was up 6/32 at 95-30/32 to yield 6.82 percent.

On tap this session are initial unemployment claims for the week of January 18 at 830 EST/1330 GMT with consensus estimates of 347,000 new claims. At 1300 EST/1800 GMT, the Treasury will auction $12.5 billion of five-year notes, unchanged from last month's offering size.
The dollar posted solid gains overnight, firmly above the 119 yen threshold and steady in tight ranges above 1.64 marks after the German Bundesbank left interest rates unchanged.
"There's really not a thing going on. We opened a little higher, but it's quiet and should be all week," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities Inc.
Levenson said he expected a cautious mood among market participants ahead of the Treasury's auction this afternoon.
On Wednesday, the Fed's Beige Book was released early and some players said that created some disruption ahead of the two-year note auction.
Kevin Flanagan, economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., didn't buy that theory, however.

"When was the last trime the market reacted to the Beige Book in a significant way? The more likely explanation is that the Street took on a lot more paper than it originally thought it had to and had to start discounting it," Flanagan said.
The two-year initially was expected to bring in yields of 5.99 percent to 6.00 percent and only fetched 5.98 percent.
Because of that, the five-year may see a higher yield, Flanagan said. In when-issued trading, the five-year was at 6.32 percent in early trading.
The two-year note was at 99-23/32, unchanged to yield 6.02 percent. The five-year was up 1/32 at 99-6/32 to yield 6.32 percent and the 10-year was up 2/32 at 99-21/32 to yield 6.55 percent.
Three-month bill rates were down one basis point at 5.02 percent. Six-month rates were unchanged at 5.11 percent and year bill rates were also unchanged at 5.29 percent.
